Award.AwardTitle: Developmental Integration and the Ecology of Life Histories in Phylogenetic Perspective

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Of central importance in the science of human biology, as well as that of other species, is full understanding of the complex processes that underlie development, including both the integration of these processes and their evolutionary bases. While experiences during the critical period of childhood are known to have important and lasting effects on future growth, reproduction, health and behavior, the fundamental biology of this system remains poorly understood. This is especially salient for the human species, which has the longest juvenile phase of any animal. By incorporating a phylogenetic approach that examines physical, hormonal, and behavioral development in our closest living relative, the chimpanzee, we can advance understanding of this critical period of development, and determine how different developmental trajectories interact with each other and with the environment to produce adult traits. Comparison of chimpanzees and humans will provide a model for the ways in which biological influences combine with the ecological and social environments to generate adult characteristics, and contribute to understanding when and how unique features of human life history arose in our lineage (such as early weaning, prolonged reliance on parental support, and the adolescent growth spurt).

By using a series of novel, non-invasive techniques, this study will achieve the first detailed documentation of the development of wild chimpanzees, and provide the basis for a comparative, phylogenetic approach to the science of primate, including human, development. Trajectories to be analyzed include physical growth (linear growth, body weight, muscle mass, and tooth eruption), nutrition (behavioral measures of nursing intensity, hormonal measures of maternal and infant energy balance, and isotopic measures of maternal and infant diet), hormones (testosterone, cortisol, estradiol, progesterone, DHEAS and C-peptide), and multiple dimensions of behavior. Hypotheses to be tested will assess how maternal condition, early life nutrition, stress, and related factors influence the timing and rates of development, and the role of hormones in these interactions. The results will be important for understanding sex differences in physiology and behavior. Ultimately, understanding these relationships will allow us to better infer life history shifts associated with changing habitats, ecologies, and morphologies in the hominin evolutionary lineage.

Numerous domestic and international broader impacts are tied to the project. Data generated by the research will be utilized to promote K-12 education in the U.S., working with teachers in both New York and New Mexico to enhance curricula and foster science literacy and appreciation. Education and training of both U.S. and Ugandan undergraduate and graduate students will be fostered through incorporation of these students into the project, and through utilization of the generated data for future research. International collaboration and capacity building, as well as conservation of endangered species, will be promoted by providing economic incentives for protection in Kibale National Park (job creation, training, research fees), supporting anti-poaching and ecotourism programs, and educating Ugandan primary school children about wildlife and habitat conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To better understand patterns of human development, this research sought answers to five questions about the development of chimpanzees, our closest living relative, in the wild. First, what are the basic patterns of chimpanzee development (including musculoskeletal growth, dental development, weaning, hormonal development, and behavioral development)? Second, how variable are these patterns among individuals? Third, how does the health and nutritional status of the mother affect the growth and development of her infants? Fourth, are different types of development (e.g. dental vs. musculoskeletal) linked, such that early development of one means early development of the other. If so, is such linkage coordinated by hormones? Finally, how do patterns of chimpanzee development compare to human patterns, and what can the similarities and differences tell us about the evolution of human development?

To answer these questions, we combined previously collected, long-term data with new observations. During the grant period we collected >13,000 hours of behavioral data, >7000 urine samples (for analysis of hormones and molecules indicating muscle growth), thousands of photos (to document dental and musculoskeletal development), and fecal samples from new infants for genetic analysis.

Data analysis for this project is ongoing, but some findings are clear:

1. Compared to captive individuals, wild chimpanzees exhibited a delayed increase in pubertal testosterone, a delayed adolescent growth spurt, and an extended adolescent growth period. Testosterone increased sharply around ages 7-9, when males also showed increased independence from their mothers, and increased levels of aggression compared to females. Although skeletal growth was completed around age 10, full musculature was not achieved until 15-16, when males also reached adult testosterone levels. Consistent with the potential role of testosterone in linking different aspects of development, males who showed earlier developmental increases in testosterone also showed earlier increases in muscle mass, higher adult levels of testosterone, and greater muscle mass in adulthood.

2. We established developmental standards for the eruption of both deciduous and permanent teeth in chimpanzees. Unlike skeletal maturation, the ages of eruption for deciduous teeth and first molars in the wild were nearly identical to those in captivity. Later forming teeth, however, were delayed in the wild, erupting in the latter half of the captive range and beyond.

3. Mother’s condition had a surprising effect on infant development. High-ranking mothers had better (higher-energy) diets, and consequently maintained shorter intervals between births. Chimpanzees born after shorter birth intervals, however, were significantly smaller than those born after longer intervals. Offspring growth appeared to be compromised by the withdrawal of mother’s nutritional investment during early weaning. As a result, chimpanzee mothers in good condition produced more, but lower-quality, infants than those in poor condition.

4. Genetic paternity analyses permitted us to characterize the development of chimpanzee fatherhood. Males started reproducing in adolescence, around the same time as females. Males showed a distinct peak in fertility in their early twenties, when testosterone and muscle mass also peaked. Males subsequently showed a steady decline in fertility until age 40, after which few sired offspring. Mothers maintained a comparatively stable rate of reproduction across the same ages. Adolescent males managed to successfully sire offspring by targeting adolescent females, who were neglected by adults. The few males who lived past age 45 continued to reproduce by forming alliances with the alpha male, who allowed them to mate in return for their support. In foraging and other small-scale human societies, by comparison, men show less of a peak in fertility during youth, probably because the importance of long-term pair bonds in human reproduction makes men and women’s fertility schedules more similar.

5. Behavioral data revealed clear sex differences in chimpanzee sociality, some beginning in infancy. Infant play showed clear sex differences, with males initiating more bouts than females, and engaging in higher rates of rough-and-tumble play. In contrast to human children, chimpanzees of both sexes exhibited a preference for male play partners. Mothers of young infant (0-1 year old) sons spent more time associating with adult males compared to when they were the mothers of daughters. While there was no sex difference in the amount of time that focals spent watching their neighbors grooming, males were more likely than females to groom immediately following exposure. Males that watched longer were even more likely to groom afterward. Sex differences in chimpanzee behavior are thus likely shaped both by differential social exposure and underlying differences in attention.

Male chimpanzees were more aggressive than females starting around 7-8 years, when male testosterone levels started to rise. Male aggression tracked male fertility, peaking in the early 20’s and declining steadily thereafter. Males exhibited significantly higher rates of aggression than females throughout adulthood (3-12 times higher). Testosterone appeared to facilitate aggression by making males more likely to respond to perceived status challenges from others, a dynamic that is also likely found in human men.
